channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Senior ISIS Strategist and Spokesman Is Reported Killed in Syria
item.media:description: Abu Muhammad al-Adnani, a founding member of the Islamic State, oversaw the group’s external terrorist operations.
item.description: Abu Muhammad al-Adnani, who was behind the Islamic State’s call for attacks against Western interests around the world, died in Aleppo Province, the group said.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT and ANNE BARNARD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Israel Quietly Legalizes Pirate Outposts in the West Bank
item.media:description: Children in the Mitzpe Danny outpost this month in the Israeli-occupied West Bank. Mitzpe Danny is part of an expansive network of about 100 outposts established mostly over the past two decades without government authorization.
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.description: Unauthorized settlements dot hilltops in the West Bank, and anti-settlement groups and Palestinians say retroactively legalizing them is a methodical effort to change the region’s map.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: North Korea Has Executed a Deputy Premier, Seoul Reports
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, in a picture issued by his government’s Korean Central News Agency.
item.media:credit: KCNA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, has executed the deputy premier for education, Kim Yong-jin, and purged two other senior officials, South Korea said.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Japanese Government Urges Another Increase in Military Spending
item.media:description: Tanks from Japan’s Ground Self-Defense Force during a drill last week in the foothills of Mount Fuji.
item.description: Missile defenses are a major focus amid challenges from North Korea and China. But the budget proposal is a test of Japan’s commitment to pacifism.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Safety Tip for Visitors From India’s Culture Minister: ‘Don’t Wear Skirts’
item.media:description: Mahesh Sharma, India’s culture minister, in 2015.
item.description: The minister’s remarks drew broad criticism in a country trying to convince female tourists that they need not fear sexual assault.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR

item.title: France’s Burkini Debate Reverberates Around the World
item.media:description: A woman in a burkini this month in Marseille, France.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: In other countries, the body-covering swimwear has been embraced as a symbol of modesty, liberation and even diversity.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Isle of Mull Journal: A 600-Year-Old Money Pit in the Scottish Highlands
item.media:description: Tourists at Duart Castle this month on the Isle of Mull, Scotland, when scaffolding was erected for repairs. Work has been underway on the 14th-century castle since Sir Lachlan Hector Charles Maclean of Duart and Morven inherited it from his father in 1990.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: The Maclean clan’s castle, with its leaky walls and collapsed ceilings, sits on an island where blustery, rainy weather makes a need for repairs constant.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Spain’s Interim Leader Bids to Form New Government
item.media:description: Mariano Rajoy, Spain’s caretaker prime minister, on his way to deliver his speech before Parliament on Tuesday.
item.description: Mariano Rajoy, the caretaker prime minister, is trying to end the deadlock that has left Spain without an elected government since December.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Passenger Jet Service From U.S. to Cuba Starts Wednesday
item.description: JetBlue is to become the first American airliner to fly scheduled service to Cuba in more than 50 years. Six airlines have been approved for flights.
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: Truck Bomb Kills 15 in Somalia; Shabab Claim Responsibility
item.media:description: Emergency personnel and soldiers gathered at the scene of a truck bomb in Mogadishu, Somalia on Tuesday. The attack killed at least 15 people.
item.description: A truck loaded with explosives blew up outside of a popular hotel in Mogadishu where government officials were meeting.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN and HUSSEIN MOHAMED

item.title: The Interpreter: Does Killing Terrorist Leaders Make Any Difference? Scholars Are Doubtful
item.media:description: Turkish Army tanks last week at the Syrian-Turkish border. In a statement on Tuesday, the Islamic State said Abu Muhammad al-Adnani, a senior leader of the Islamic State, had been killed.
item.description: Terrorist organizations have features that make them resilient in the face of a senior officer’s death, researchers have found.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Consular Visit Is a Rarity for American Held in North Korea
item.media:description: Otto F. Warmbier, an American student, at the Supreme Court in Pyongyang, North Korea, in March.
item.description: Otto F. Warmbier, a student sentenced to 15 years of hard labor, has received just one visit in nearly six months from the Swedish diplomats who look after American consular interests.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Police in China Push for Trial of Tibetan Education Advocate
item.media:description: Tashi Wangchuk, a Tibetan entrepreneur and education advocate, could face up to 15 years in prison if convicted of inciting separatism.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: Tashi Wangchuk has been investigated for interviews he did last year with The New York Times and could face 15 years in prison on a charge of inciting separatism.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Emmanuel Macron, Eyeing French Presidency, Resigns as Economy Minister
item.media:description: Emmanuel Macron, France’s economy minister, spoke at a news conference in Paris on Tuesday after his resignation was announced.
item.description: Mr. Macron, who challenged many Socialist Party orthodoxies and infuriated France’s unions, said he was stepping down to “undertake a new step in my struggle.”
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Aid Group’s Gaza Branch Manager, Accused of Diverting Funds to Hamas, Is Arraigned
item.media:description: Mohammad El Halabi, the manager of the Gaza branch of World Vision, a Christian aid organization, is accused of infiltrating the charity on behalf of Hamas.
item.description: Mohammad El Halabi, of World Vision’s Gaza branch, is accused by Israel of funneling $43 million to Hamas. He was arraigned at a closed hearing on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Mob in Ukraine Drives Dozens of Roma From Their Homes
item.media:description: A still from a video taken on Sunday of Ukrainian police officers escorting Roma residents from the village of Loshchynivka, Ukraine.
item.description: Residents blamed them for the rape and death of a 9-year-old, but a rights group noted that the suspect who was arrested was not of that ethnic group.
item.dc:creator: LINCOLN PIGMAN

item.title: China, Eager to Host Elite Club, Primps for G-20 Meeting
item.media:description: Police officers in Hangzhou, China. President Xi Jinping has ordered stringent security to ensure that the Group of 20 summit meeting goes smoothly.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: As it prepares for its biggest summit yet, China is forcing residents out of nearby towers, idling factories and ordering workers to take vacation.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ and YUFAN HUANG

item.title: Sinosphere: Chinese Women Head Overseas to Freeze Their Eggs
item.media:description: A women’s egg being prepared for in vitro fertilization in Beijing. Because unmarried women are barred from assisted reproductive procedures in China, more are going to the United States and other countries to have their eggs frozen.
item.description: Beijing allows only married couples to undergo fertility treatments, so many single women are looking abroad to give themselves more time to have children.
item.dc:creator: CAROLYN ZHANG

item.title: 15 Philippine Soldiers Killed in Clashes With Abu Sayyaf Militants
item.media:description: Troops carrying dead bodies last week after a military operation against Abu Sayyaf in the southern Philippine province of Sulu.
item.description: The government also announced plans to deploy about 2,500 more soldiers, or five battalions, to the group’s stronghold in the south.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: Suicide Bomber Attacks Chinese Embassy in Kyrgyzstan
item.media:description: Damage to the Chinese Embassy building. Three Kyrgyzstani staff members were wounded, according to local officials.
item.description: Three people were wounded in the assault, which the Central Asian country’s government called “a terrorist act.”
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Singapore Says It Expects More Zika Cases
item.description: With 82 confirmed cases as of Tuesday and thousands of premises to be inspected, health authorities said they will likely find more infections.
item.dc:creator: WEIYI LIM

item.title: American Is Facing Spy Trial in China, and Husband Seeks Obama’s Help
item.media:description: Phan Phan-Gillis, an American business consultant from Houston, has been detained in China since March 2015.
item.description: Phan Phan-Gillis, a Houston businesswoman, was detained last year on allegations dating back 20 years. President Obama is being urged to bring up the case.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: What in the World: Never the Noodles Shall Meet: A Chinese Treaty Is Tested
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin; photo by DoctorPic/Shutterstock
item.description: Halal food is big business in China. But to the Hui, a Muslim ethnic minority, a social pact may come before profit in the placement of halal noodle shops.
item.dc:creator: EMILY FENG

item.title: What in the World: Corpses, Pythons, Sleep Deprivation: Meditation Rituals in Thailand Can Be Intense
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin; photo by Marilyn Barbone/Shutterstock
item.description: At some Buddhist temples, methods include meditating beside a dead body, to learn about selflessness, or in total darkness, to enhance concentration.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Editorial: Neighbors Question Cuba Migration Policy
item.media:description: A Cuban migrant, hoping to travel north to the United States, at a temporary shelter in Costa Rica.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: Nine Latin American governments urge Washington in rare public rebuke to rescind its indefensible preferential immigration policy for Cubans.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Australia’s Gulag Archipelago
item.description: The conditions of refugee detention centers on remote islands are a national disgrace. But can shame force reform?
item.dc:creator: JULIA BAIRD

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Can We Save Venice Before It’s Too Late?
item.description: Tourism threatens to destroy one of Italy’s most historic cities. The United Nations has issued a stern warning.
item.dc:creator: SALVATORE SETTIS
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

item.title: Photo Editors’ Notebook: What Makes the Image of Omran Daqneesh Extraordinary?
item.media:description: The front page of The New York Times on August 19 featured a photograph by Mahmoud Raslan of a 5-year-old boy who was rescued after an airstrike in Aleppo, Syria.
item.description: “It’s a difficult question for even the most seasoned photo editor to answer.”
item.dc:creator: CRAIG ALLEN

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Notebook: How Many Guns Did the U.S. Lose Track of in Iraq and Afghanistan? Hundreds of Thousands.
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers after receiving new rifles from U.S. forces in Baghdad in May 2007.
item.description: A new study shows how the American military failed at the soldier’s most basic responsibility: keeping track of firearms.
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Talking to Terrorists
item.media:description: Harry Sarfo, a former Islamic State fighter from Germany, inside the maximum-security prison in Bremen where he is serving a three-year sentence on terrorism charges.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: For once, the conversation wasn’t via social media, and the name the Islamic State defector used was the one on his birth certificate.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
